claim: Interest is money paid for borrowing money

supporting.text: Interest is a financial charge imposed by a lender on a borrower for the use of borrowed funds, as defined in standard economic and financial textbooks.

attacks.text: Interest is a financial charge imposed by a lender on a borrower for the use of borrowed funds, as defined in standard economic and financial textbooks.
In Islamic finance, interest (riba) is prohibited, and alternative profit-sharing arrangements are used instead of traditional interest-based loans.
Islamic finance still involves compensation for the use of funds, which functionally resembles interest, even if it is not labeled as such.
Some jurisdictions have usury laws that cap interest rates, making the definition of interest context-dependent rather than universally standardized.
Usury laws regulate the amount of interest but do not change the fundamental economic definition of interest as a charge for borrowing.

supporting.text: In loan agreements, interest is explicitly stated as the cost of borrowing money, calculated as a percentage of the principal amount.

attacks.text: In loan agreements, interest is explicitly stated as the cost of borrowing money, calculated as a percentage of the principal amount.
Some loans, like Islamic loans, do not charge interest as it is prohibited under Sharia law, instead using profit-sharing or fee-based structures.
Islamic loans still effectively compensate the lender for the time value of money, which is economically equivalent to interest, just under a different name.
In hyperinflationary economies, nominal interest rates may be negative in real terms, meaning the lender loses purchasing power despite receiving interest.
Negative real interest rates are temporary anomalies and do not negate the fundamental definition of interest as compensation for lending.

supporting.text: Central banks and financial institutions universally recognize interest as compensation for the risk and opportunity cost of lending money.

attacks.text: Central banks and financial institutions universally recognize interest as compensation for the risk and opportunity cost of lending money.
Some Islamic financial systems prohibit interest (riba) entirely, viewing it as exploitative, which contradicts the universal recognition claim.
Islamic finance still incorporates profit-sharing or fee-based structures that functionally resemble interest, just under different legal and ethical frameworks.
During periods of negative interest rates, lenders effectively pay borrowers, reversing the conventional definition of interest as compensation.
Negative interest rates are temporary policy tools, not a rejection of the fundamental economic principle of interest as compensation for lending.

supporting.text: Legal systems enforce the payment of interest as a contractual obligation in debt instruments, confirming its role as money paid for borrowing.

attacks.text: Legal systems enforce the payment of interest as a contractual obligation in debt instruments, confirming its role as money paid for borrowing.
Some religious or cultural systems prohibit interest (e.g., Islamic finance), treating it as unethical rather than a contractual obligation.
Even in systems prohibiting interest, alternative financial structures (e.g., profit-sharing) fulfill similar economic functions, effectively serving as interest under another name.
Interest is sometimes waived or forgiven in cases of financial hardship, undermining the strict contractual enforcement claim.
Waivers or forgiveness are exceptions, not the norm, and do not negate the general legal enforceability of interest.

supporting.text: Interest rates are publicly disclosed in financial markets, reflecting the cost of borrowing money across various credit products.

attacks.text: Interest rates are publicly disclosed in financial markets, reflecting the cost of borrowing money across various credit products.
Some interest rates are not publicly disclosed, such as private loan agreements between individuals or businesses.
Even private loan agreements often reference publicly disclosed rates as benchmarks, maintaining transparency.
Interest rates may not fully reflect the true cost of borrowing due to hidden fees or penalties.
Regulations in many jurisdictions require full disclosure of all borrowing costs, including fees and penalties.
